031E9611124E401287E9ED1F6062717D.description: Explain how historical American inventors and entrepreneurs used their ideas to help others (e.g., Robert Fulton, Samuel Morse, Alexander Graham Bell, Thomas Edison).

CDF8678373C14FCBB5CB335187479F32.description: Describe how setting goals and creating a budget help people obtain their needs and wants.

C0A810E821E749F78550347C20022987.description: Explain the costs and benefits of spending and saving in order to meet one’s needs and wants.

2214426306F64032B9362F7EEA511C28.description: Compare the roles of consumers and producers in the American economy and explain how individuals are both producers and consumers.

A9FED8079D334C0A891B2CB9DB2A3076.description: Explain how people are paid for their labor and how some people own their own businesses to earn money.

DB7B0BEEC94E437F9318E0FE1B94B505.description: Explain how goods are produced from natural resources using human labor, identifying examples of goods and services that people in the local community produce (e.g., agricultural products, oil and gas, aerospace industry).

7AFCF35463404B538C20E885D7FB89E3.description: Differentiate between natural resources and human-made products.

DB14EDC2FCBB430D912B0149EB32D10B.description: Explain how Americans are free to make choices about what to buy and that choices are necessary because they cannot have everything they want.

6A27B6796A894472867AD094AA44CD23.description: The student will describe the characteristics of free enterprise.

CAC77339929A4A7A9DFC64C117E4A06F.description: Define culture and identify the elements of culture (e.g., language, customs, religion, food, clothing), using examples relevant to student experiences.

991176E445D84879979F6B4855155003.description: Describe how the physical environment affects occupational and recreational opportunities in the local community and region.

699264EE1B5E40C5AF828E8F5737CE9B.description: Identify how the physical environment of the community has been modified to meet specific needs (e.g., agricultural crops, forestry, dams).

98E135F801F8465FAE4F69A5C97396E8.description: Identify ways in which people adapt to the world around them (e.g., specific clothing for different climates, storm shelters).

522C859F563D4852916872EE24AD9236.description: Identify natural resources (e.g., water, soil, vegetation, minerals) and describe how people use natural resources to meet their needs and wants.

82A11909EE094AF58AD54052787151D8.description: Identify cardinal directions and use them to identify specific locations on a map and globe, including the location of the national capital, Washington, D.C., and the Oklahoma state capital.

34EC84A684644CB9AAC681E6A3D7CA7A.description: Distinguish between landmasses and bodies of water on a map and globe, identifying the continent of North America and the countries and oceans bordering the United States.

EBDAF6C691E34ADAB42D72C490900340.description: Construct maps of specific places, such as the community and state, and describe the relative location of physical and human features.

3C07ED37B2EE481E9C8D0AAA96AECE70.description: Describe the difference between physical and political maps and how each can be used to inform about the world.

10E2F92BD06D44EAB6F48E5A119EC309.description: Explain that a globe is a model of the Earth and that maps can be used to represent local places or specific regions of the state, nation, or world.

421C766AA8D64D35886F1396355D397E.description: The student will demonstrate knowledge of basic geographic concepts.

C1252C7B1F7C4756AC6CDDD3C9B37719.description: Describe the contributions of people and groups commemorated on national holidays (e.g., Veterans Day, Thanksgiving, Presidents’ Day, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, Independence Day).

8ECE6D253FCD42498886E5A4AC8911AE.description: Identify stories about people and ideas from Judaism that influenced the American colonists, the Founders, and American culture (e.g., David and Goliath, Moses and the Ten Commandments).

13A363582D434484BF14905D2B026605.description: Explain how Americans from different cultural backgrounds immigrated to the United States, comprising and contributing their traditions to our national heritage.

330DABF4DA6D4D09B13F6C9F23316717.description: Explain how American Indians played a role in their original homelands and thrive in Tribal communities today.

AA15CDF781E744DF9F3BE947EBC5A3EA.description: Compare the ways individuals and groups in the local community and region lived in the past with how they live today (e.g., housing, communication, transportation, occupations).

6FB7CDBA02824636A433A75060793426.description: Read and construct basic timelines of related events to demonstrate an understanding of the concept of chronology, as well as cause and effect relationships.

5AD838C1A5BB456489B9E0EEEA88D133.description: Identify primary sources (e.g., letters, photographs, diaries, newspapers, official papers) and explain how they help us learn about the past through firsthand accounts.

A2B985AC964B47FA8C8BD663405FE188.description: Describe and explain the meaning of important symbols of the United States (e.g., Bald Eagle, Liberty Bell) and examine how American symbols, holidays, and celebrations help to develop a shared sense of history and community.

C6A6F5D30D9345B6BBB4F05FF1FFE05D.description: The student will examine how we learn from the important events and people of the past.

EE462490817F405096E5B698C4BC8A9A.description: Public Service (e.g., Benjamin Franklin, George Washington, James Madison).

68BE7109E7F74C2A801DFB18F717895D.description: Science and Technology (e.g., Benjamin Banneker, Meriwether Lewis, William Clark)

ACB1AB20BF084A66B9D6C557977AB970.description: Military Service (e.g., John Paul Jones, Nathan Hale)

1E603C67E1D24407BD9CEEFD1BA7F4AD.description: Leadership (e.g., Chief Powhatan, Patrick Henry, Thomas Jefferson)

BBD2D6BEACD644BE9353D333677B2FC3.description: Using biographies from early American history, explain historical examples of patriotism and civic virtue as exemplified during the early American republic, including

D02AA8F3A7344DC1AB9F8D1DB29B02F0.description: Identify and explain the meaning of the United States’ official motto, "In God we trust," including the importance of religion to American people.

81D83EB641774488869D3665632F8E4C.description: Explain how we celebrate our nation and its history through patriotic songs (e.g., "My Country, 'tis of Thee," "God Bless America”).

7CE412900FE44C758D7B0619BB81C970.description: Examine ways citizens can demonstrate patriotism, including military service, honoring veteran cemeteries, and celebrating Independence Day.

35B451CD024E4DFF9322000D9030C824.description: Explain appropriate ways to show respect during the playing of the national anthem, “The Star- Spangled Banner,” by Francis Scott Key.

F0A7231FFFF7463F9CB097094DB99C0F.description: Describe appropriate flag etiquette for both the national and state flags.

8130EB4ABA7B43C8BB18EF8BE36F023D.description: Explain the purpose and the meaning of the Salute to the Oklahoma Flag.

F3C4ECF442CA40499509D23BCEE01825.description: Explain the purpose and meaning of The Pledge of Allegiance and the significance of the phrase “under God.”

9A1E4C89D74E4BC486906727CA9939BA.description: Explain patriotic traditions that unite citizens.

ECA494CE4A6448FEACAFD321A9380430.description: Describe how citizens within communities work together to accomplish common tasks, using examples relevant to student experiences.

4E9790A180D247ACA5C41FAF24E514D8.description: Define the concept of civic duty, identifying characteristics of responsible citizenship in a democracy (e.g., respect for laws, voting, and volunteerism).

BA5078B692B9400FA286864B13D39C7D.description: Explain how leaders in our state and nation are elected by citizens to make laws for the protection of people and their property.

04B40F5D4E944F6C9C5B52676B958A8D.description: Define a democracy as a form of government in which citizens make decisions for their communities.

92B768F589F247A6B1ADB811ECB5D283.description: Identify the basic purposes of government and explain how governments protect citizens' rights, while providing for the common good.

3B756406970349B993920345D37D345D.description: The student will analyze their role as a citizen in a community.

14E7A99DE09F4F53B211849735BFBD13.description: With guidance and support, deliver a simple presentation to communicate ideas and thoughts.

3FF49BC90106436FAB7204144B827261.description: Organize information found during group research, using graphic organizers and other aids with guidance and support.

89C1C69FE651489A99CCCC0B7F67D7AB.description: With guidance and support, generate a list of topics of interest and questions about social studies.

909FD7F9F3A140DFA60F6ABDA0FF7E35.description: Engage in authentic research to acquire, refine, and share knowledge through written presentations and products.

D73E6FA3092D45D49EB49C0E7FE7631D.description: With guidance and support, draw, label, dictate, and write to express an opinion, providing reasons as support.

E0CD0B65F58A4797A3CBF2E9D42C2C55.description: Draw, label, dictate, and write an informative product with guidance and support.

0846C680D257459C9AFA09953B4ED6A8.description: Summarize and paraphrase, integrate evidence, and cite sources to create written products, research projects, and presentations for multiple purposes related to social studies content.

000E13F126314D5DA891ABD639490AF7.description: The student will develop a variety of evidence-based written products designed for multiple purposes.

4E9C214E724F415284DF5A3CC448313A.description: Ask and answer basic questions and engage in collaborative discussions about appropriate topics in a text.

29C3356E914945298300C1E50FFBEF7D.description: Locate facts that are clearly stated in a text (e.g., who, what, where, when, why, how).

BFEED6DC263F42C1B44CE5E57DD0B48F.description: Identify the author’s purpose, with guidance and support.

E3C58825163944AFA08D4D65928207B7.description: Apply critical reading and thinking skills to interpret, evaluate, and respond to a variety of complex texts and perspectives.

250306FE782F4BBEADFC65DF58AFA462.description: Use titles and graphic features, including photographs and illustrations, to understand a text.

D7C2AC70115D4EE9BB812565CB185C3C.description: Locate the topic or main idea and supporting details of a text.

F8CB1178B4854CBEB920C2C7DB84228D.description: Comprehend, evaluate, and synthesize textual sources to acquire and refine knowledge in the social studies.

40B51BE0B9DA4C9D99F296F91262711E.description: The student will engage in critical, active reading of primary and secondary sources related to social studies concepts.

3A0902F40BB044138A4F69F94C0E264A.description: Identify examples of the goods and services that school and community workers provide.

C651C34E1DD1441595C2561AEFD00CF7.description: Identify needs and wants, including the concept of freedom of choice.

C78D324B436A4FB1BCEA002B24964501.description: Collaboratively gather simple economic data from graphs.

DF25A8DDCD1A4A9C9ACC05BA86EA444D.description: Identify the principles of economic systems and develop an understanding of the benefits of a market system in local, national, and global settings.

7FD8FAE03775477A8129E45A467E6B99.description: Identify how the physical environment impacts our daily lives and affects human activities.

B956C68F6A9B42E9A35FA1A6DBCDC85A.description: Identify and describe the community’s human and physical environment through the use and creation of simple maps and photographs of the community.

2F1E17F522C5461597768E6AEB82FD1C.description: Answer geographic questions using geographic information about the student’s own community.

101E7C7794EE4AA38344097FE2FAE059.description: Demonstrate a mastery of geographic concepts and the use of geographic tools to understand the impact of geography on the past and present.

66ADEC01D4C243FB9FC7CD56358D2067.description: Explain possible reasons for an event and make simple timelines which reflect cause-effect relationships, with guidance and support.

F8C9AABB935048CF9C5C361BCD6BCCAC.description: Identify point of view and examples relevant to the student’s experiences.

F1AC1B5A9AD54166878018186D4DD8E0.description: Identify a primary source of information and with support, gather basic information (i.e., author, date, facts).

921574D2FBAE42A8BD89A1B24A2462DC.description: Develop skills which demonstrate an understanding of historical events and the people who shaped our history.

78656411CB954693BC477B2B36AC5C99.description: Describe the purposes of rules in various settings (e.g., family, classroom, school), how rules are made, and consequences for violating rules.

0E7F80BF41C44093B0A9FF2B802DB415.description: Identify responsibilities of people in authority in school and community settings.

E4CAEBBCA0F34DA18CF431B4BE20B8F2.description: Identify democratic principles such as equality, fairness, and respect for the law.

253BC711B31643018E8014A7499B362E.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the principles of government, the benefits of democratic systems, and their responsibilities as citizens.

36D7290007254EB0BD1A54F95C4E6D3C.description: The student will use interdisciplinary tools to acquire, apply, and evaluate content understanding of the four strands of social studies.

CDBDF63538FD4F1AA8E5BD9A869BBFE0.description: With guidance, demonstrate understanding of social studies content through completion of authentic tasks.

F18373909071407FA29DD71E295A5EE4.description: Practice critical thinking skills by responding to various levels of open-ended questions.

649C3380ECF84F068E66EE71E38915EF.description: Use supporting questions to help guide learning of specific social studies content.

2E9506DEB60D4DA78569A7DB86389883.description: Collaboratively ask and respond to essential questions of common concerns to the student and community.

09D97EA196A54271B7EEE7687FCE504C.description: Develop practices which demonstrate an understanding that social studies involves the evaluation of evidence.

F267CD00BFAB47FA8104B74A1B56AAED.description: Identify and discuss local problems and ways in which people are trying to address these problems.

718BC3025BB941719DE816DD4589D39E.description: Engage in democratic processes to address authentic, real-world problems in the classroom.

FD5D9D6409024E52B68FEDC53D8372F8.description: Describe how people can work together to make decisions in the classroom and school.

8A71A16E47AB419091764F13B462027D.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the virtue of civil discourse to analyze and address real-world problems.

82FE3158016E46D4A2DFFCB3F1661B35.description: The student will apply critical thinking skills to address authentic civic issues.
